awd_titl_txt: Beta-Decay Experiments along the R-Process Path
awd_abstract_narration:
Most of the chemical elements in the universe have been produced by nuclear reactions in stars through a series of different nucleosynthesis processes. The basic features of most of these processes are well understood. However, one of the major open questions is the nature of the rapid neutron capture process (r-process), which is responsible for the synthesis of roughly half of the chemical elements heavier than iron, such as gold and uranium. Astronomical observations indicate that the r-process has been active since the early stages of galactic history, and takes place in explosive stellar environments, such as supernovae explosions or mergers between two neutron stars, but the details are not known. A major difficulty to understanding the r-process is that it involves unstable isotopes.  The main activities supported by this award are a series of nuclear physics experiments to measure the radioactive decay properties of isotopes directly relevant to r-process studies. The experimental setup combines state-of-the-art radiation detectors for beta-decay measurements (BRIKEN), and unstable isotope beams at leading accelerator facilities in Japan (RIBF) and the US (NSCL). The nuclear data obtained in this experiments will allow for a more precise comparison between astronomical observations and astrophysical models for the r-process.  Another objective of this proposal is to provide students, especially at the undergraduate level, with opportunities to become involved in research activities at the forefront of nuclear physics, and contribute to expanding the number of students pursuing scientific careers in the US.  For this reason, the proposal includes research projects that will take place at the campus of Central Michigan University (CMU), such as the development of radiation detectors and computational work with astrophysical models of the r-process.

The main scientific outcome of this award will be the measurement of beta-delayed neutron emission probabilities (Pn values) with the new BRIKEN detector setup at the Radioactive Ion Beam Factory in RIKEN, Japan. The BRIKEN setup consists of an active stopper detector for radioactive ion beams, surrounded by a high-efficiency neutron detector composed of He-3 proportional counters. The experiments currently planned will measure Pn values, as well as decay half-lives, for neutron-rich isotopes spanning the regions from the N=50 shell closure up to the rare-earth elements. These experiments will provide new nuclear data for r-process models in regions of the nuclear chart relevant to address important questions of r-process nucleosynthesis, such as the astrophysical conditions that lead to the formation of elements in the A=130 abundance peak.  The award will also support the participation of CMU researchers in r-process experiments at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory (NSCL) at Michigan State University. This includes a project to develop reaccelerated beams of heavy isotopes around the N=82 region, with the potential to open new opportunities for r-process measurements.

por.por_cntn:
One of the unresolved mysteries of nuclear astrophysics is that of the origin of the heaviest chemical elements. Most elements heavier than iron are made by stellar nucleosynthesis processes that involve the capture by atomic nuclei of free neutrons present in the astrophysical environment. The material ejected in extreme explosive astrophysical events, like a core-collapse supernova at the end of the life of a massive star or the collision between two neutron stars in a binary system, can contain a large amount of free neutrons. Through a sequence of rapid capture reactions of these free neutrons, followed by radioactive beta decays, the chemical elements up to uranium are synthesized in just a few seconds by a process called the rapid neutron-capture process (r-process).

In recent years our understanding of the r-process has benefited significantly from new astronomical observations, such as the discovery of direct signatures from the synthesis of heavy chemical elements in the afterglow of the collision between two neutron stars (event detected by gravitational waves as GW170817), or the measurement of the abundances of r-process elements in old stars in our Galaxy that show a remarkable similarity to the chemical composition of the Sun. However, key questions about r-process nucleosynthesis are still unresolved, for example regarding the degree at which supernovae contribute to the synthesis of heavy elements, or the possibility that there are diverse kinds of r-process events depending on the amount of free neutrons available in different astrophysical scenarios. Because the chain of nuclear reactions in the r-process involve very short-lived isotopes, many of which have not yet been produced and studied in a laboratory, the uncertainty in the nuclear data needed to model the r-process is a serious limitation to answer these questions. Our project helped to address the lack of sufficient nuclear data for astrophysical models of the r-process.

The award "Beta-Decay Experiments along the R-Process Path" supported the participation of researchers from Central Michigan University (CMU) in the activities of the Beta-delayed neutrons at RIKEN (BRIKEN) collaboration. The BRIKEN collaboration assembled a state-of-the-art neutron detector for radioactive decay experiments at the Radioactive Isotope Beam Factory (RIBF) in the RIKEN laboratory of Japan. A high-efficiency neutron detector using 3He proportional counters was used in a campaign of experiments to study decay properties of a large number of unstable isotopes, focusing on the measurement of neutrons emitted during their radioactive beta-decay (beta-delayed neutrons). The probability of this type of decay mode is a key nuclear physics input for r-process models.

The CMU group had a leading role in two of the BRIKEN experiments. One of them measured delayed neutrons for isotopes from rhodium to tin, including isotopes with a number of neutrons at and near the so-called neutron magic number of N=82. The experiment measured the probability for emission of delayed neutrons for 53 isotopes, with 20 measured for the first time [1,2]. The second experiment studied unstable isotopes of selenium to yttrium, with mass number around A=100 [3]. These are isotopes in a region where the structure of the atomic nuclei can change rapidly with the addition of a few neutrons, in particular with changing nuclear shapes, in what represents a challenge for theoretical models that aim to predict their properties. The experiment measured the probability of emission of delayed neutrons for 23 isotopes (16 of them for the first time), and beta-decay rates of 13 isotopes for the first time (Figure 1).

Nucleosynthesis by the r-process was modelled including the results of our experiments. They confirmed that the isotopes studied in the region of neutron number N=82 play a important role in the synthesis of elements between tellurium to xenon, which form the so-called A=130 r-process abundance peak. Our new data contributes to reducing significantly the nuclear physics uncertainty in the abundance of elements in the A=130 abundance peak [1,2]. We also performed r-process simulations using the measured data in isotope with mass number around A=100, which show that the results have an impact in models of nucleosynthesis in the material ejected by core collapse supernova.

A key goal of the project was to train undergraduate students, supporting their first research experiences, and help with the growth of the STEM workforce in the US. This proposal supported the work of 4 CMU undergraduate students in research projects involving development of nuclear physics instrumentation, astrophysics simulation and data analysis work. The measurement of decay properties of A=100 isotopes was the main Ph.D. project of one CMU student.

[1] O. Hall et al, Physics Letters B 816, 136266 (2021)
[2] V. H. Phong et al, Physical Review Letters (accepted 2022)
[3] Neerajan Nepal, PhD Thesis, CMU (2022)
